title: Decreased Cardiac Output Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for managing decreased cardiac output, focusing on optimizing cardiac function, preventing complications, and improving tissue perfusion in patients with various cardiac conditions.

assessments.title: Cardiovascular Assessment
points: Assess heart rate, rhythm, and blood pressure q2-4h and PRN
Auscultate heart sounds for S3, S4, murmurs, or gallops
Evaluate for jugular venous distention
Assess for presence of peripheral edema and document degree (1+ to 4+)
Evaluate peripheral pulses and capillary refill time
Monitor for chest pain or discomfort
assessments.description: Comprehensive cardiovascular assessment helps identify signs of decreased cardiac output and guides therapeutic interventions

assessments.title: Respiratory Assessment
points: Assess respiratory rate, depth, and pattern q4h
Auscultate lung sounds for crackles, wheezes, or decreased breath sounds
Monitor oxygen saturation continuously or q4h
Assess for orthopnea, dyspnea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
Evaluate for cough or hemoptysis
Monitor for signs of pulmonary edema
assessments.description: Respiratory assessment helps detect pulmonary complications of decreased cardiac output, particularly pulmonary congestion

assessments.title: Perfusion Assessment
points: Evaluate level of consciousness and mental status
Assess skin color, temperature, and moisture
Monitor urine output hourly in acute situations
Assess for signs of decreased peripheral perfusion (cool extremities, delayed capillary refill)
Evaluate for abdominal distention or hepatomegaly
Monitor renal and liver function tests
assessments.description: Perfusion assessment helps identify end-organ effects of decreased cardiac output requiring intervention

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Decreased Cardiac Output related to altered contractility, preload, or afterload as evidenced by tachycardia, dyspnea, and fatigue
relatedFactors: Altered heart rate/rhythm (tachycardia, bradycardia, heart blocks)

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Activity Intolerance related to imbalance between oxygen supply and demand as evidenced by dyspnea and fatigue with activity
relatedFactors: Imbalance between oxygen supply and demand
definingCharacteristics: Abnormal heart rate or blood pressure response to activity
Electrocardiographic changes reflecting ischemia or arrhythmias

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved cardiac output as evidenced by stable vital signs and improved perfusion parameters
indicators: Blood pressure within patient's normal range

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved activity tolerance with minimal symptoms
indicators: Able to perform ADLs with minimal fatigue
Heart rate and blood pressure remain stable with activity
Demonstrates use of energy conservation techniques

interventions.title: Hemodynamic Regulation
actions: Administer cardiac medications as prescribed (diuretics, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, inotropes)
Position patient in semi-Fowler's or high Fowler's position
Implement fluid restrictions as ordered
Monitor daily weights and strict intake and output
Administer oxygen therapy to maintain SpO2 >92%
Implement progressive activity plan based on tolerance
rationales: Medications optimize cardiac contractility, preload, and afterload
Upright positioning decreases preload and improves pulmonary ventilation
Fluid restriction prevents volume overload in compromised heart
Weight and I&O monitoring helps evaluate fluid status and diuretic response
Supplemental oxygen improves myocardial oxygenation
Gradual activity prevents deconditioning while avoiding cardiac strain
specialConsiderations: Adjust interventions based on etiology of decreased cardiac output
Consider more intensive monitoring for severe cardiac dysfunction

interventions.title: Cardiac Care: Acute
actions: Maintain continuous cardiac monitoring
Monitor for and treat arrhythmias per protocol
Minimize unnecessary physical and emotional stress
Cluster nursing activities to provide rest periods
Assess response to medications and report adverse effects
Prepare for and assist with advanced interventions if needed (IABP, mechanical circulatory support)
rationales: Continuous monitoring detects arrhythmias that may further compromise output
Prompt treatment of arrhythmias prevents further deterioration
Stress reduction decreases myocardial oxygen demand
Rest periods reduce cardiac workload
Medication response assessment guides therapy adjustments
Advanced interventions may be necessary for severe cardiac dysfunction

expectedOutcomes: Vital signs within patient's normal range
Improved peripheral perfusion (warm extremities, capillary refill <3 seconds)
Resolution of S3 heart sound if previously present
Effective use of energy conservation techniques

references.author: Yancy CW, Jessup M, Bozkurt B, et al.
references.title: 2017 ACC/AHA/HFSA Focused Update of the 2013 ACCF/AHA Guideline for the Management of Heart Failure
references.source: Journal of the American College of Cardiology

references.author: Heidenreich PA, Bozkurt B, Aguilar D, et al.
references.title: 2022 AHA/ACC/HFSA Guideline for the Management of Heart Failure

notes: Consider palliative care consultation for patients with end-stage heart failure and refractory symptoms despite optimal medical therapy
timeFrame: Acute management 3-5 days, ongoing for chronic management

title: Excess Fluid Volume Management
description: A care plan focused on assessing and treating patients with excess fluid volume to prevent complications such as pulmonary edema and impaired tissue perfusion.

assessments.title: Fluid Status Assessment
points: Monitor daily weight at the same time of day
Assess intake and output strictly each shift
Inspect for peripheral and generalized edema
Auscultate lung sounds for crackles
Assess jugular venous distention
Monitor serum electrolytes
assessments.description: Accurate assessment identifies severity of fluid overload and guides intervention priority.

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Excess Fluid Volume related to compromised regulatory mechanisms as evidenced by edema and weight gain

goals.statement: Patient will achieve euvolemia as evidenced by stable weight and resolution of edema

interventions.title: Fluid Management
actions: Implement physician-ordered fluid restriction
Administer diuretics as prescribed
Elevate edematous extremities
Educate on low-sodium diet
rationales: Restriction prevents additional overload
Diuretics promote fluid excretion
Elevation facilitates venous return
Sodium control reduces water retention

evaluations.statement: Is fluid volume within normal limits?

title: Activity Intolerance Management
description: A care plan aimed at improving a patient's tolerance to activity by balancing rest and graded exercise, preventing exacerbation of cardiac workload.

assessments.title: Tolerance Assessment
points: Measure vital signs before, during, and after activity
Assess for dyspnea, chest pain, or dizziness with exertion
Use Borg scale to gauge perceived exertion
Evaluate ability to perform ADLs
Monitor oxygen saturation with activity
assessments.description: Baseline and ongoing assessment helps tailor activity plan to individual tolerance.

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Activity Intolerance related to imbalance between oxygen supply and demand as evidenced by exertional dyspnea and fatigue
definingCharacteristics: Abnormal vital sign response to activity

goals.statement: Patient will tolerate increasing activity without adverse symptoms
indicators: Stable vital signs with graded activity

interventions.title: Activity Progression
actions: Develop and implement a graded exercise plan
Provide rest periods between activities
Educate on energy conservation techniques
Assist with adaptive devices as necessary
rationales: Gradual increase prevents overexertion
Rest prevents oxygen debt
Energy conservation reduces fatigue
Adaptive devices support independence
